headline.main: Two Reports Identify High-Cost Patients; High Cost of Health Care Lessons to Be Learned Study Demonstrates a Link

docs.abstract: Study by Christopher J Zook and Dr Francis D Moore indicates that high-cost patients are far more likely to smoke, abuse alcohol, be overweight or engage in 'adverse lifestyles'; findings, published in recent issue of New England Journal of Medicine, are partially confirmed by 2d study by Rhode Island Group Health Assn; health care analysts believe that establishing identity of high-cost patients is an important factor in formation of any economically feasible national health insurance plan (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON THE findings of two new studies have shed light on who puts the heaviest burden on America's health care system, an important factor in establishing any economically feasible plan for national health insurance.
docs.snippet: WASHINGTON THE findings of two new studies have shed light on who puts the heaviest burden on America's health care system, an important factor in establishing any economically feasible plan for national health insurance.
